thread.title: UCLA: McCaffrey, Stanford run over Bruins 56-35
thread.title_full: UCLA: McCaffrey, Stanford run over Bruins 56-35 - Press Enterprise

author: JOEY KAUFMAN
title: UCLA: McCaffrey, Stanford run over Bruins 56-35
text:
BY JOEY KAUFMAN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 15, 2015 Updated: Oct. 16, 2015 1:17 a.m. PALO ALTO – No quarterback in college football history had ever gone 5-0 against one team.
That changed Thursday night at Stanford Stadium.
For the fifth time since 2012, Stanford senior quarterback Kevin Hogan marched the Cardinal to a win over UCLA, this time by the largest margin yet, 56-35.
It marked the most points the Bruins had allowed in a game in Coach Jim Mora’s four-year tenure, as Stanford went on to beat them for the eighth consecutive time, a streak that dates to 2008.
Hogan may have grabbed the historical footnote, but it was Christian McCaffrey who proved to be UCLA’s undoing.
McCaffrey rushed for 243 yards and four touchdowns on 25 carries, setting a school single-game record by surpassing Toby Gerhart‘s 223-yard effort against Oregon in 2009.
The jitterbug running back was electric from the get-go, picking up a 25-yard run on his first carry, then returning a kickoff 96 yards the second time he touched the ball to set up No.15 Stanford (5-1 overall, 4-0 Pac-12) for its second score.
McCaffrey, who entered the game ranked second in the FBS in all-purpose yards, posed problems all night for 18th-ranked UCLA (4-2, 1-2), finishing with 369 all-purpose yards before taking a seat early in the fourth quarter.
The Bruins fell behind, 35-10, late in the second quarter.
Penalties proved costly for UCLA early on. The Bruins were flagged six times in the first half, some of them stalling drives.
When senior receiver Jordan Payton caught a short pass from freshman quarterback Josh Rosen to pick up a first down on the Bruins’ first drive, he was whistled for pass interference on a pick play, running into a defensive back to set another receiver free.
That left UCLA with a third-and-16 from its own 14-yard line. Rosen fired the ball toward the sideline, but his pass was underthrown and intercepted by cornerback Alijah Holder, who cut across the field and returned it 31 yards for a touchdown and an early 7-0 lead.
On UCLA’s second drive, the Bruins marched to the Stanford 10-yard line. The drive included a shifty run from Paul Perkins, who juked past several defenders, then cut across the field for a 43-yard gain. He appeared to score on a 10-yard run, but right tackle Caleb Benenoch was hit with an offside penalty.
A holding penalty two plays later meant the drive ended with a 36-yard field goal by kicker Ka’imi Fairbairn.
McCaffrey returned the ensuing kickoff 96 yards before being chased down by Fairbairn and brought down by Octavius Spencer.
The Cardinal extended their lead to 14-3 on the next play, Hogan’s 4-yard touchdown pass to Austin Hooper.
